State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China Graphical abstract Supported noble metal catalysts have been widely utilized for HCHO catalytic oxidation. When the active components are fixed, the altering and regulation of the supports would have a huge effect on catalytic performance. Here, two types of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different support size (micro-γ-Al2O3 and nano-γ-Al2O3, respectively) were fabricated and used for HCHO oxidation. Compared with the micro-sized counterpart, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited much superior HCHO oxidation performance which could totally oxidize 160 ppm of HCHO into harmless CO2 under a WHSV of 100,000 mL gcat −1 h−1 at room temperature. Multiple characterizations including XRD, BET, TEM, CO chemisorption, FT-IR, O2-TPD, XPS and in situ DRIFTS were implemented to study the effect of γ-Al2O3 support size on physicochemical properties of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and elucidate the structure-activity relationship. The results revealed that large specific surface area, rich surface OH groups as well as high curvature of nano-γ-Al2O3 not only facilitated HCHO adsorption, but also stabilized highly dispersed Pd species which then promoted the activation of oxygen and boosted formate species decomposition, and consequently leading to the enhanced HCHO oxidation performance of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3. This work deepens the comprehension of support size-dependent activity of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for HCHO oxidation and provides an alternative method to prepare high-performance Pd catalysts for HCHO oxidation. Keywords Adsorption HCHO oxidation High dispersion Pd/γ-Al2O3 Size effect 1 Introduction As a ubiquitous indoor air pollutant, formaldehyde (HCHO), mainly released from building and decorative materials, has great harmful to human health due to its strong irritation and carcinogenicity and has been classified as Group 1 probable human carcinogen by International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) in 2004 [1,2]. Therefore, it is of vital importance to abate airborne HCHO in view of human health and increasingly stringent environmental regulations. Over the last few decades, a myriad of techniques have been developed for the indoor HCHO elimination, including adsorption [3], photo-catalytic oxidation [4], plasma degradation [5] and catalytic oxidation [6–10]. Among them, catalytic oxidation of HCHO under mild conditions has been considered as the most promising candidate owing to its overwhelming advantages in terms of removal efficiency and operating convenience [11–14]. Since seminal work done by He et al. in Pt/TiO2 catalyst for room temperature HCHO catalytic oxidation [15], various supported noble metal catalysts (such as Pt/Co3O4, Pd/TiO2, Au/CeO2) have been constructed and applied for this reaction [16–20]. Recently, supported Pd catalysts have drawn enormous research interest because of the relatively high catalytic activity and excellent stability [21–23]. For example, Huang et al. [24] prepared a Pd/TiO2 catalyst which could achieve the total oxidation of HCHO at ambient temperature owing to its strong oxygen activation ability. In general, the HCHO oxidation activity is significantly affected by the dispersion of active components. For supported Pd catalysts, improving the Pd dispersion is regarded as an effective method for enhancing their HCHO oxidation activity [11]. However, the highly dispersed Pd particles tend to suffer from heavy agglomeration due to the high surface energy [25]. In order to address this problem, a great deal of efforts have been made in stabilizing well-dispersed Pd particles. For instance, Zhang et al. [26] prepared a highly dispersed Pd/TiO2 catalyst by high temperature reduction in which well dispersed Pd particles could be trapped and stabilized by the aid of strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), and thus a superb HCHO oxidation activity was obtained. In addition, Zhang et al. [27,28] also synthesized a series of well dispersed Pd/TiO2 catalysts through introducing the alkali Na. Benefiting from the stabilization effect of Na species on Pd particles, the Na doped Pd/TiO2 catalysts exhibited higher Pd dispersion and much better HCHO oxidation performance than the pristine Pd/TiO2. In addition to the two methods mentioned above, the altering and regulation of the supports also have a huge influence on noble metal particle size (dispersion) for supported noble metal catalysts [29,30]. For instance, Qi et al. [31] reported that the nano-sized Al-HMS supported Pd catalyst possessed much higher Pd dispersion in comparison to the micro-sized counterpart. And benefiting from its abundant active sites, the Pd/nanosize Al-HMS showed superb benzene oxidation activity. Analogously, Shi et al. [32] also found that the small-sized HZSM-5 supported PtAg catalyst exhibited higher specific surface area and PtAg dispersion than the medium and large sized HZSM-5 supported PtAg catalysts, consequently resulting in its improved benzene storage and oxidation performance. As inspired by the above literatures, we suppose that the small-sized support (especially the nano-sized support) might be beneficial for stabilizing well-dispersed Pd particles, which in turn improves the HCHO catalytic oxidation performance. Nevertheless, the application of nano-sized carrier supported Pd in HCHO oxidation reaction has been rarely reported. On the other hand, as a common porous materials, γ-Al2O3 has been extensively utilized in the fields of adsorption and catalysis owing to the large surface area, low cost, and exceptional stability [33–35]. For example, Chen et al. [36] synthesized a series of surfactant templates (CTAB, P123, and SDS) modified γ-Al2O3 and found that P123 modified γ-Al2O3 displayed a significantly enhanced HCHO adsorption capacity because of its large surface area and adequate surface OH. Arias et al. [37] prepared a Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst which achieved 100 % HCHO conversion at 90 °C. And on this basis, they further improved the HCHO oxidation activity of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by Mn doping. In spite of some progress, unfortunately, ambient temperature HCHO oxidation over Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts is still an arduous challenge and the HCHO complete conversion temperature of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts is commonly higher than 80 °C to our knowledge [23,37,38]. Hence, in order to further enhance the HCHO oxidation activity of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, the nanosized γ-Al2O3 (nano-γ-Al2O3) was applied as carrier to support Pd. For comparison, the microsized γ-Al2O3 (micro-γ-Al2O3) supported Pd catalyst was also prepared. The results manifested that the HCHO oxidation performance of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 was much superior to that of micro-sized counterpart. Various characterization methods were performed to study the influence of γ-Al2O3 support size on physicochemical properties of corresponding Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and clarify the structure-activity relationship. Furthermore, based on the results of in situ DRIFTS, a plausible HCHO oxidation mechanism over Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 was also proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The micro-γ-Al2O3 (average particle size ca. 1.5 μm) and nano-γ-Al2O3 (average particle size ca. 10 nm) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and Aladdin, respectively. Aqueous Pd(NO3)2 was gotten from Aladdin. Deionized water was employed throughout the experiments. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The two kinds of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different support size were prepared via the impregnation method using micro-γ-Al2O3 and nano-γ-Al2O3 as the carriers respectively and the nominal Pd content was 1 wt%. Specifically, 2 g of γ-Al2O3 powder was firstly dispersed in 50 mL of deionized water by stirring and then a certain amount of aqueous Pd(NO3)2 was added into the suspension. Afterwards, the moisture of suspension was completely evaporated at 50 °C. The resulting powders were dried at 100 °C overnight followed by calcining in air at 550 °C for 2 h with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min. The two types of catalysts were denoted as Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3, respectively. In the end, the as-prepared catalysts were treated with 10 % H2/N2 (150 mL/min) at 300 °C for 0.5 h prior to evaluation. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Pd loading of catalysts was detected by ICP-OES (Agilent 5110) and the results are listed in Table 1 . Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were conducted using a D8-Advanced diffractometer (Bruker) equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source. The BET surface area and pore characteristics of samples were analyzed by N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (Autosorb-iQ-MP). The microstructures and morphologies of samples were discerned by transmission electron microscopy (FEI, Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin). The Pd dispersion of catalysts was determined by CO chemisorption (ChemStar TPx) and the theoretical ratio of CO to surface Pd atom was 1. The FT-IR spectra was recorded on a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer. To prevent the implication of moisture, all samples and KBr were dried at 105 °C for 2 h before test. O2-TPD experiments were conducted employing a ChemStar TPx apparatus. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) patterns were tested utilizing an AXIS ULTRA DLD photoelectron spectroscopy. In situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out on a Tensor 27 spectrometer (Bruker). Firstly, the catalysts were pretreated with pure nitrogen at 150 °C for 1 h to eliminate impurities and then cooled to ambient temperature to record background spectra. Subsequently, 30 mL/min of reactant gas (160 ppm HCHO/20 %O2/N2, relative humidity = 60 %) was introduced into in situ cell and the spectra was collected continuously by background subtraction. 2.4 Performance tests The performance tests of HCHO catalytic oxidation were conducted in a fixed-bed U-shaped micro-reactor (4 mm i.d.) utilizing 120 mg of catalyst (40–60 mesh). A total flow of 200 mL/min was employed (WHSV = 100,000 mL gcat −1 h−1) and the feed gas consisted of HCHO (160 ppm), O2 (20 %), H2O (60 % relative humidity) and N2 balance. The effluent gas were monitored continuously with a DX-4000 FTIR gas analyzer (Gasmet Technologies). The HCHO conversion of samples was calculated using the following equation: (1) HCHO Conversion (%) = [ CO 2 ] out - [ CO 2 ] in [HCHO] in ×100% Where [HCHO]in and [CO2]in are the inlet HCHO and CO2 concentration, respectively. [CO2]out represents the outlet CO2 concentration. No by-products other than CO2 was detected in the effluent gas during activity testing and the CO2 selectivity results of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 are showed in Table S1. Turnover frequency of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was defined as the number of converted HCHO per surface Pd atom per seconds and the detailed calculation formula was as follows: (2) TOF = [HCHO] in ∙C HCHO ∙V gas ∙M Pd m cat ∙w Pd ∙D Pd ∙R g Where mcat represents the weight of catalyst (g), wPd is the Pd loading (%), DPd is the Pd dispersion of catalyst determined by CO chemisorption (%), Rg represents the gas molar volume at 25 °C (24.5 L/mol), CHCHO represents the HCHO conversion rate (<15 %), Vgas represents the gas flow rate (L/s), MPd represents the relative atomic weight of palladium (g/mol). HCHO breakthrough experiments over micro-γ-Al2O3 and nano-γ-Al2O3 supports were carried out under the same reaction conditions with activity test and the adsorption temperature was constant at 25 °C. Likewise, the outlet HCHO concentration was monitored continuously with the DX-4000 FTIR gas analyzer until the outlet HCHO concentration raised to inlet values. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 HCHO oxidation performance evaluation 3.1.1 Activity test The HCHO conversion of samples as a function of temperature is presented in Fig. 1 . Both the bare micro-γ-Al2O3 and nano-γ-Al2O3 supports were inactive for HCHO catalytic oxidation at range from 25 °C to 70 °C. After the introduction of 1 wt% Pd, the HCHO oxidation activity increased tremendously. For the Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the HCHO conversion was 74 % at 25 °C and increased to 100 % with raising the reaction temperature to 70 °C. Comparatively, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited much higher HCHO oxidation activity and achieved 100 % HCHO conversion at 25 °C. As far as we know, it is the first time that complete HCHO oxidation is achieved over γ-Al2O3 supported Pd catalyst at ambient temperature. Moreover, compared with some reported Pd based catalysts for HCHO oxidation (Table S2), the as-prepared Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalyst manifested a higher HCHO conversion at ambient temperature under harsher reaction conditions (higher inlet HCHO concentration and WHSV), further confirming its superior HCHO oxidation activity. On the other hand, the effect of some operating parameters including Pd loading, O2 concentration (transient response experiment), relative humidity (RH), inlet HCHO concentration and WHSV on HCHO oxidation activity of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 was also systematically investigated and the results are depicted in Fig. S1-S5. All of these demonstrated that the as-prepared Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalyst possessed excellent HCHO oxidation activity. 3.1.2 Stability test Apart from reaction activity, the long-term stability of catalyst for HCHO oxidation is also vital in view of operating convenience and cost. The 24 h long test results of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 are presented in Fig. 2 . The HCHO conversion of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 decayed rapidly with prolonging test time and it was only equivalent to 44 % of initial conversion after 24 h test. In sharp contrast, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 exhibited exceptional stability for HCHO oxidation and no perceptible activity decline could be detected during the whole process of reaction. In short, the as-prepared Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalyst might be a desirable candidate for catalytic oxidation of HCHO at ambient temperature as a result of the high activity, stability as well as no by-products. 3.2 Characterization results Powder XRD measurements were implemented to study the crystal structure of samples. As seen in Fig. 3 , all samples displayed typical γ-Al2O3 diffraction peaks (JCPDS 02-1420) and the peaks appeared at 19.6, 31.9, 37.6, 39.5, 45.8, 60.5, and 66.8° were ascribed to (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (511), and (440) faces of γ-Al2O3, respectively [29,37]. Note that, for the Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3, the diffraction peak at 40.1° was indexed to (111) plane of metallic Pd (JCPDS 46-1043) [25]. In contrast, no diffraction peaks associated to Pd species (Pd or PdO) were detected on the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3, implying that Pd species should exist as smaller particles on the nano-γ-Al2O3 support which were favorable for its HCHO oxidation performance. The pore characteristics of samples were probed by N2 sorption isotherms. As displayed in Fig. 4 , all of samples presented a type IV isotherm which indicated that there existed mesoporous structure, in accordance with BJH pore size distributions [39]. Specifically, the hysteresis loop of micro-γ-Al2O3 was assigned to H2 type which was the characteristics of ink-bottle pores. While the nano-γ-Al2O3 presented a hysteresis loop of H3 type, revealing the presence of piled pores. The Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 exhibited similar isotherms with their corresponding γ-Al2O3 supports, demonstrating that the introduction of Pd species did not change the pore types of supports. As presented in Table 1, the nano-γ-Al2O3 possessed relatively higher BET surface area and pore volume in comparison to the micro-γ-Al2O3, meaning that the nano-γ-Al2O3 could provide much adequate sites to adsorb HCHO and anchor Pd species which not only benefited HCHO adsorption but also contributed to HCHO oxidation. In addition, compared with the pristine γ-Al2O3 supports, a slight decrease in BET surface area and pore volume was observed after loading Pd species, presumably due to the pore blockage by Pd particles. The supports morphologies and Pd particle size of samples were discerned by TEM and the corresponding TEM images are depicted in Fig. 5 . The micro-γ-Al2O3 exhibited an irregular plate-like morphology and its average particle size was about 1.5 μm, indicating that it belonged to micro-scale support. On the contrary, the nano-γ-Al2O3 was formed by stacking of tiny spherical nanoparticles (radius ca. 5 nm), which was in coincidence with N2 sorption isotherms results (Fig. 4). On the other hand, the curvature of support (1/radius) increases with the decrease of radius of support, consequently nano-γ-Al2O3 with small radius should possess high curvature. As reported previously, supports with high curvature generally exhibited strong interface effect, which was beneficial to stabilize well-dispersed noble metal particles [31]. When the size of Pd clusters adsorbed on nano-sized supports increased to a certain level, the high surface tension force and energy of interface would lead to the instability of Pd clusters structure which in turn could effectively suppress the growth and agglomeration of Pd particles. Therefore, it might deduce that the nano-γ-Al2O3 with high surface area and curvature should be beneficial to the dispersion of Pd species. In order to confirm the inference, we further investigate the Pd dispersion over the two types of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 showed relatively large Pd particle size and the mean Pd particle size was ca. 12.41 nm. Comparatively, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 possessed higher Pd dispersion and its average Pd particle size was only 4.49 nm, unambiguously implying that the nano-γ-Al2O3 was more favorable for stabilizing well-dispersed Pd particles, in accordance with the results of XRD and CO chemisorption (Fig. 3 and Table 1). Meanwhile, with the reduction of Pd particle size, the coordination numbers of Pd species decreased accordingly and it is widely accepted that low-coordinated Pd species usually possess higher intrinsic reaction activity in heterogeneous catalysis [25,40]. As displayed in Table 1, the turnover frequency of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 was more than double that of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3, demonstrating that the intrinsic HCHO oxidation activity per Pd active site of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 was also higher than that of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3. Therefore, benefiting from higher dispersion of Pd species, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 with more plentiful active sites and higher intrinsic reaction activity per active site manifested improved HCHO oxidation performance. In addition to the reaction activity, the HCHO adsorption ability of catalyst also has a significant influence to the performance of HCHO oxidation. Thus, we employed the HCHO breakthrough experiments to investigate the influence of γ-Al2O3 particle size on HCHO adsorption ability. As seen in Fig. 6 , the nano-γ-Al2O3 with large surface area exhibited much higher HCHO adsorption capacity compared with the micro-γ-Al2O3 (410.95 μmol/g vs 276.65 μmol/g), suggesting that the former possessed superb HCHO adsorption performance. Moreover, the HCHO adsorption capacity of γ-Al2O3 supports was normalized to the specific surface area so that it could reflect intrinsic HCHO adsorption ability of different γ-Al2O3. It could be found that specific HCHO adsorption capacity of nano-γ-Al2O3 was around 1.2 times that of micro-γ-Al2O3 (Table 2 ), demonstrating that higher HCHO adsorption capacity of nano-γ-Al2O3 was not just owing to its higher surface area but also some other factors. As is known, the surface properties of sample would also affect its HCHO adsorption performance. Thus, we next studied the surface properties of samples by FT-IR spectra and the results are displayed in Fig. 7 . The peaks centered at 3440 and 1640 cm−1 were ascribed to the stretching vibration and bending vibration of OH groups, respectively [36]. Because all samples were adequately dried prior to test, thus the detected OH groups should be ascribed to the surface Al-OH groups of γ-Al2O3. Compared with the micro-γ-Al2O3, the nano-γ-Al2O3 possessed much more abundant surface OH groups. After loading 1 wt% Pd, the OH contents of corresponding Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts both decreased but the degree was different. For the Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3, the intensity of OH groups dropped significantly. Whereas the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 only exhibited a slight reduction in the intensity of OH groups and still possessed much richer OH groups compared with the Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3. According to literatures, the surface OH groups could facilitate HCHO adsorption through hydrogen bond interaction [29,41,42]. Hence, the nano-γ-Al2O3 that possessed both relatively large surface area and adequate surface OH groups would endow Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 with excellent HCHO adsorption ability, in turn improving its HCHO oxidation activity. Fig. 8 shows the O2-TPD profiles of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalysts. As can be seen, three peaks centered at around 230, 400 and 620 °C were assigned to the desorption of surface chemisorbed oxygen molecule (O2 −), chemisorbed oxygen atom (O−) and lattice oxygen (O2-), respectively [43,44]. Obviously, it was discovered that the surface chemisorbed oxygen amounts of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 were much more than those of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3, indicating the excellent oxygen activation ability of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3. As reported previously, the activation of oxygen was an important step in the HCHO oxidation reaction and the coordinatively unsaturated surface Pd species were identified as the active centers of O2 activation for supported Pd based catalysts [11,25]. For the well-dispersed Pd catalysts, they not only possessed much adequate sites to activate O2 but also the small-sized Pd particles exhibited higher activity in O2 activation process owing to the low-coordination environment of Pd species, which jointly endowed them with superb O2 activation performance [40,45]. Hence, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 with higher Pd dispersion manifested much superior performance of oxygen activation and possessed richer chemisorbed oxygen, which then facilitated HCHO oxidation. To investigate the influence of γ-Al2O3 support size to the element chemical states of catalysts, the XPS measurements were carried out. The XPS spectra of Pd 3d is displayed in Fig. 9 a. The peak could be deconvoluted into two components at 336.5 ± 0.1 and 335.4 ± 0.1 eV, corresponding to PdO (Pd2+) and metallic Pd (Pd0), respectively [28]. The XPS spectra of O 1s is presented in Fig. 9b. The peaks appeared at 532.5 ± 0.2 and 531.4 ± 0.1 eV were ascribed to chemisorbed oxygen or surface hydroxyl (Oα) and lattice oxygen (Oβ), respectively [46–49]. The deconvolution results of XPS spectra are summarized in Table 3 . Notably, the Pd0/Pd2+ ratio of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 was nearly identical, therefore the distinct HCHO oxidation performance difference between the two catalysts was not because of Pd0/Pd2+ ratio. On the other hand, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 exhibited much higher ratio of Oα/Oβ compared to Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 (0.96 vs 0.47), which was well coincident with the results of FT-IR and O2-TPD (Figs. 7 and 8). As aforementioned, surface hydroxyl could facilitate HCHO molecules adsorption by hydrogen bond interaction, and chemisorbed oxygen is recognized as the active oxygen species for HCHO oxidation reaction [11,24,41]. Therefore, it could be concluded that adequate surface hydroxyl and chemisorbed oxygen of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 jointly enhanced its HCHO removal ability by promoting HCHO adsorption and oxidation synchronously. 3.3 HCHO oxidation mechanism In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed to get insight into the reaction pathway of HCHO oxidation over Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3. Fig. 10 a and b depict the in situ DRIFT spectrum of Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 after exposing to the flow of reactant gas (160 ppm HCHO/20 %O2/60 %RH/N2) at ambient temperature for 60 min, respectively. It could be seen that the characteristic band of HCHO (1710 cm−1) was observed over Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 during the initial stage of reaction [50]. On the contrary, no bands associated to HCHO could be detected over Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 in the whole reaction process, implying that HCHO was more easily oxidized over Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 which could be ascribed to its adequate surface chemisorbed oxygen species, evidenced by O2-TPD and XPS (Figs. 8 and 9). The sharp band at 1640 cm−1 was attributed to δ(OH) of adsorbed H2O derived from feed gas and reaction product of HCHO oxidation [51]. The bands located at 1430 and 1460 cm−1 belonged to υ(OCO) and δ(CH2) of dioxymethylene (DOM), respectively [52], which was generated via nucleophilic attack of chemisorbed oxygen. The three bands at 1575, 1544 and 1340 cm−1 were assigned to υas(COO) and υs(COO) of formate species, respectively [53–55]. The weak band at 2064 cm−1 was related to linearly adsorbed CO species which were formed through the formate species decomposition [15,56]. What’s more, gaseous CO2 (2350 cm−1) was only detected over Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 [57], further confirming its superior activity of room temperature HCHO oxidation. On the basis of the above results, it could be concluded that the HCHO oxidation reaction over Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 both followed the formate decomposition route (i.e. HCHO → DOM → formate → CO → CO2). On the other hand, of particular note is the band intensity of formate species on Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 was significantly stronger than that of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3. In contrast, the band intensity of adsorbed CO species on Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 was far below that of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3. It unambiguously revealed that Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 should possess a faster formate species consumption rate. As reported previously, the formate species decomposition was considered as the rate-determining step during the HCHO oxidation [15], and thereby the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 with a faster formate species decomposition rate exhibited superb HCHO oxidation performance. At last, a possible HCHO oxidation pathway over Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3 and Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 was proposed based on the results of in situ DRIFTS. Firstly, oxygen molecules could be adsorbed and activated into active oxygen species on the coordinatively unsaturated surface Pd species (Eq. (3)). Owing to higher Pd dispersion, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 manifested superior performance of oxygen activation, thereby possessing more adequate active oxygen species in comparison to the Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3. At the same time, larger specific surface area and richer surface OH of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 endowed it with much better HCHO adsorption ability. Subsequently, HCHO adsorbed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 via hydrogen bond was quickly oxidized into DOM species by active oxygen species through nucleophilic attack (Eq. (4)) and then DOM species further transformed into formate species (Eq. (5)). Afterwards, formate species decomposed into adsorbed CO species and H2O (Eq. (6)). Finally, adsorbed CO species was further oxidized into CO2 by the active oxygen species (Eq. (7)). Benefiting from its superior HCHO adsorption ability and faster formate species decomposition rate, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 exhibited the enhanced HCHO oxidation performance. (3) O2 → 2[O]s (4) HCHO + [O]s → [H2CO2]s (5) [H2CO2]s → [HCOO−]s + H+ (6) [HCOO−]s + H+ → [CO]s + H2O (7) [CO]s + [O]s → CO2 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this study clearly clarified the size effect of γ-Al2O3 supports on the catalytic performance of Pd/γ-Al2O3 for HCHO oxidation. The characterization results indicated that nano-γ-Al2O3 played a dual role in promoting HCHO adsorption and stabilizing well dispersed Pd particles owing to its large specific surface area, abundant surface OH groups and high curvature. Meanwhile, well dispersed Pd particles of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalyst in turn promoted the activation of oxygen and boosted formate species decomposition. Eventually, benefiting from the simultaneous improvement of HCHO adsorption and oxidation ability, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 exhibited remarkably improved HCHO oxidation performance in comparison to the Pd/micro-γ-Al2O3. coredata.dc:description: Supported noble metal catalysts have been widely utilized for HCHO catalytic oxidation. When the active components are fixed, the altering and regulation of the supports would have a huge effect on catalytic performance. Here, two types of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different support size (micro-γ-Al2O3 and nano-γ-Al2O3, respectively) were fabricated and used for HCHO oxidation. Compared with the micro-sized counterpart, the Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited much superior HCHO oxidation performance which could totally oxidize 160 ppm of HCHO into harmless CO2 under a WHSV of 100,000 mL gcat −1 h−1 at room temperature. Multiple characterizations including XRD, BET, TEM, CO chemisorption, FT-IR, O2-TPD, XPS and in situ DRIFTS were implemented to study the effect of γ-Al2O3 support size on physicochemical properties of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and elucidate the structure-activity relationship. The results revealed that large specific surface area, rich surface OH groups as well as high curvature of nano-γ-Al2O3 not only facilitated HCHO adsorption, but also stabilized highly dispersed Pd species which then promoted the activation of oxygen and boosted formate species decomposition, and consequently leading to the enhanced HCHO oxidation performance of Pd/nano-γ-Al2O3. This work deepens the comprehension of support size-dependent activity of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for HCHO oxidation and provides an alternative method to prepare high-performance Pd catalysts for HCHO oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Size effect of γ-Al2O3 supports on the catalytic performance of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for HCHO oxidation
